reviewText:
It was a dangerous journey, they knew that. But HornyFishMan, NuggleSnugg, and HurgaDerga had to do it. It was time they traveled to the West Coast in their trusty station wagon. Leading the group, HornyFishMan picks up his uzi. They hunt. Bandits attack. Some could even aim. They reach a river. They ford it. Boulders... so many boulders... and then the pirate ship attacked. Luckily, there was a rocket launcher in the river. A few quick shots, and it's down. Suck it, Blackbeard.

The group enters the Great Plains. Buffalo buffalo buffalo. The number of buffalo was absurd. HurgaDerga is impaled by a buffalo, and I swear he will be missed. NuggleSnugg and HornyFishMan go on. Horny is healed by health kits that was bought, along with a flame thrower, with the buffalo hide. Remember, the ones that killed HurgaDerga? Revenge is sweet. They see a woman in a red dress. HornyFishMan stops to see if she needs help. It wasn't a trap, and she needs no help. She thanks Horny and sends him away. A civil war battle is underway nearby. The group says hello. There were no survivors.

The group reaches another river. It was time the station wagon went underwater. Water buffalo water buffalo water buffalo. The group reaches an island. Horny notices supplies on the shore. He takes them. It was a trap! PELICANS! Luckily, he survives. They swim to shore.

They reach a mountain pass. Food supplies were running low, so they hunted. No bandits this time, but wolves. So many wolves. They find a trader. They use the wolves they murdered to buy a double-barreled uzi. There is a snow storm, yet the wolves continue to attack. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s... They deal with the wolves, and see a strange figure in the distance... Horny investigates.

BIGFOOT! Horny runs at him, and having found another flamethrower in the snow, takes him down easily. It is now out of ammo, though, so he gets his double-barreled uzi back out. Infinite ammo rocks! He runs back to the wagon, and the snow storm was rough, so in their panic, they drive off a cliff.

Buffalo followed HornyFishMan and NuggleSnugg off the cliff. So many buffalo. They dodge all the buffalo, and manage to land safely in a river. Having lost their wheels, the station wagon became a raft. They navigated through boulders and fought off alligators. Then they reached a bandit ambush. The bandits attacked with shotguns on their rafts. Successfully defending themselves from the bandits, alligators, and boulders, the group could see the West coast. They almost made it! But then a bandit showed up. He had found some sort of steam boat. Lighting up the boat as much as possible, it wasn't enough. A bandit holding a shotgun on top of the steam boat fired, and Horny wasn't quick to the dodge. NuggleSnugg joined Hurga, after all this time. She came so far, and it didn't even matter. Horny, in all his rage, blew up the boat with his uzi, ending his bandit problem. Reaching shore, Horny shoots pelicans in celebration. He made it to the West coast, though he lost his best friends. He will never forget that fateful Super Amazing Wagon Adventure.

No game makes me smile the way that Super Amazing Wagon Adventure does.

The love that went into making this game -- by a one-person studio, no less -- is evident from the moment that the title screen is displayed.

At first glace, the lo-fi visual style is deceptively simple. But as you experience each new scenario, the passion and care that went into creating this specific experience becomes more and more evident.

Those visuals are supported by a soundtrack that is simply a joy to listen to. Each phase of the wagon's journey has an overall theme that effectively sets the mood. When the final track begins, the anticipation of reaching the coast is palpable.

reviewText:
A parody of The Oregon Trail edutainment games.

Graphics are intentionally retro 8bit, with a CRT monitor filter you can optionally enable. Simplistic, low-detail sprites represent your wagon, your party and anything else that may or may not want to kill you - and the former grossly outnumber the latter.

Equally retro are the sound effects, with beeps and blops and a catchy MIDI-ish soundtrack.

Gameplay is like a sillier Oregon Trail - normally you control your wagon along a linear course, avoiding obstacles and shooting at things that (rarely don't) want to kill you. Your party has individual life bars and you lose once all of them are dead or missing. Events pop up after every gameplay section, ranging from shooting train robbers, to choosing between fording or jumping a river, to some rather spoiler-y occurences.

There's the main campaign mode, and progressing through it and beating certain challenges can unlock survival modes (last as long as possible in a gauntlet of enemies), shuffle modes (your starting settings are randomized from what I understand) and new wagons (which change your speed, party's health and firepower).

It's a small game and gets you a few laughs when you play short sessions of it, and it's probably in your best of interests not to take it too seriously, even if it does get a tad dark and difficult (especially difficult).

reviewText:
The short version is for 2.99 this game is an absolute steal.  I absolutely recommend this game 100%.

Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is a game that made the YouTube rounds a while back and for very good reason.  It's one of those absurd hilarious games that just refuses to stop surprising you hour after hour.  It starts off as a pretty standard Oregon Trail inspired adventure as you customize your party, and pick a wagon.  Then after that first ten seconds I'm pretty sure the game takes a handful of shrooms and maybe coke right to the face and goes completely off the rails.  This game isn't trying to have a compelling narrative, it doesn't want to be IGN's game of the year, and it's not trying to tun the industry upside down with it's wicked angsty edginess.  No, SAWA is a game that just wants to be fun.  It wants to take you an adventure infused with pure randomness and heart of comedy gold.  You'll jump rivers and end up in space, you'll go looking for food and end up tripping balls, you'll be making your way across the plains and then fighting a Buffalo filled tornado.  A FREAKING BUFFANADO!

Visuals- The atari style graphics are simple yet endearing, and the color is perfect for the cartoony feel.  It's not winning any awards but it's perfect for the game.

Replayability- This game has it!  Not because this game offers new wagons and things to unlock, but because you just can't stop from wondering what could be next.

Sound-  Similar to the visuals, it's good but not mindblowing.  It's everything this game should be.

Gameplay_  The shooting can be a bit on the garbage side which is a shame.  You'll die a surprising amount, and what you die from will usually be even more surprising.  This game at points doesn't seem to follow any rules either.  I was once killed by a bear with no way to defend myself.  If this kind of thing bothers you, may be best to look else where.

reviewText:
Take the famous Oregon Trail, discard most of the historical facts and add a lot of random nonsense and you get Super Amazing Wagon Adventure!

Cruise through forests, fields, deserts and even underwater in your trusty wagon and try to stay alive!
And staying alive isn't so easy with almost everything out to get you! Bandits, wild animals, zombies and mother nature are trying to stop you from reaching your goal.
So what do you do? Offense is the best defense, right? So just shoot everything!
Your starting wagon gives you only a weak pistol, but you might find a lot of other weapons on your way, including shotguns, flamethrowers, bazookas and even an airstrike!
Unlock more wagons with better starting weapons, including the Diseased, which spreads disease! Or how about the Glitch, which shoots...stuff!

Most of the time the game is a sidescrolling shooter. You man your wagon and fire away, but once in a while you'll have to leave your wagon and fight on foot and it's fun all the way.
It might be a bit unfair from time to time, depending on what scenes you end up in, but the game is rather short anyway, so just try again! A great game for in between!
It's also really cheap and if you're into sillyness, this game is worth a consideration!

reviewText:
Short version: This game has unicorn ambushes, rabid squirrel attacks, and river jumping. You should buy it.

Slightly longer version: This game is merciless, unforgiving, and totally ruthless, just as an Oregon Trail homage should be. You are in a wagon and have a gun to shoot things. Sometimes you get out of the wagon to shoot things. If you are lucky you get medical recovery items and better guns, from shotguns to carpet-bombing airplanes. If you are not lucky, your three characters get horrible diseases and die to machine-gun-armed bandits and Civil War fights. More often than not, the latter will build up and have your journey end terribly.

What keeps the game from getting overly frustrating (at least for me) is the humor. This game is hilarious, and it has everything from dinosaurs to satellites. The narration is fantastic, and it is worth playing for that alone. It's why I got the game, despite usually not being a fan of these types of games. Super Amazing Wagon Adventure was just too funny to skip.

It controls well, once you get the hang of it. I personally am terrible with keyboards for games, but from how it felt, I'm fairly certain a keyboard-savvy player will usually be perfectly fine. There are plenty of options as well, ranging from a number of wagons you can unlock to survival modes. With the numerous scenarios your playable party can get into, it has high replayability.

This game is $3 for a base price, and the witty narration is worth that alone. Add in the other great factors, such as the unlockables and tight controls, and you have a huge winner. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go back to dying to buffalo.

reviewText: Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is a side scrolling shooter. It's very clearly based on games from the 80s. You have to get your wagon from point A to point B... and shot things along the way. There are cool powerups, interesting little random events that may help or harm your run, traders to buy things from, and multiple forks in the road to keep the game fresh and replayable. There are also different unlockable wagons to use, each with their own advantages, disadvantages, and special quirks. There's not a whole lot more to say about the gameplay. It's mostly just automatically scrolling to the right as you move around the screen and shoot. It can be pretty easy or very hard depending on your choices and your luck. It's rather short, but highly replayable. I love the art style and the soundtrack is also pretty freakin' catchy. Plus the appropriate sound effects, of course. I really wish I could write a longer, more detailed review, but that's all there really is about it. It's fun, addictive, and only costs 3 bucks at full price. If you enjoy games you can complete in a sitting, this is great. And it keeps you coming back for more with the random events and different wagons. The only downside for this game is that... I wish there was more. More stuff in it. A longer trail. More events. Just... more everything. But I can't fault the game for any of that because what it DOES have is all great and makes for a wonderful experience that not many games aim to give you anymore. If you're thinking about it, just get it. You might not sink hundreds of hours into it, but the ones you DO put into it will all be worthwhile playtime, no filler.\n\nSuper Amazing Wagon Adventure gets an 8/10 for being a very fun little experience with lots of replayability and that throwback feeling.

reviewText:
Frustrating, but not in a good way.

I'm a fan of roguelite games; Binding of Isaac and Enter the Gungeon are two of my favourites, so I have no problems with a game that's tough as long as it's fair. Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is *not* fair though, so prepare to die. A lot. When there's more or less nothing you could do about it.

Your hitbox is the entire wagon (large), but the area your default weapon can attack is one small line right ahead of you. You will get hit many, many times by enemies just above or just below this area charging toward you. Anyone who makes it to the Buffalo will know what I mean. There are other weapons, but there's no way to store or change them, so if you get something that could help you later you can prepare to fire it off about two minutes before you really need it.

Your wagon has three passengers, among whom damage is shared". Hits land not-really-randomly on your party members
date: often hitting and killing one person before the other two. It's possible to get hitpoints back but this happens on a purely random basis
recommended: and consists of either events that may or may not happen or medkit pickups you may not be able to reach. The frustration that comes when you find a rare event only to realize it's your 1-HP guy instead of your 4-HP guy that you have to try to finish it with... agonizing.\n\nThere's some laughs to be had here; I thought it was hilarious when I had the option to either ford a river or jump over it
hoursPlayed: and then later either go around or swim under the river. There's also a ton of content and different paths your adventure might take; I was still finding new ones until I finally quit playing.\n\nIt's a shame I'm not going to see the end of the game though because I cannot put up with these deaths that I have no real control over. If the hitbox on the wagon was a lot smaller and my gun could aim a little I'd probably play the hell out of this game. Sadly

Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is Oregon Trail meets WarioWare as a scrolling shoot 'em up. Essentially you are thrown into a variety of bizzare scenarios where you shoot and dodge stuff for about 30 seconds or less, and then there's a short transition and you're suddenly somewhere else shooting and/or dodging other stuff. For example, you might be crossing a river dodging boulders, and then you'll make it across the river and into the prairie where you'll gun down some buffalo. The general order of events never changes (forest-->river-->plains-->desert/second river-->mountain-->freefall-->rapids/present day) but there are special random events that can occur, including everything from unicorns to time travel to pirates, many of which will unlock new wagons.

SAWA is really fun, but also difficult. I've only completed it once, and I had to use the invisible wagon, which has a super tiny hitbox. Thankfully it has a good sense of humor and charming visuals and music to ease the pain of my many, many deaths.

Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is Oregon Trail meets WarioWare as a scrolling shoot 'em up. Essentially you are thrown into a variety of bizzare scenarios where you shoot and dodge stuff for about 30 seconds or less, and then there's a short transition and you're suddenly somewhere else shooting and/or dodging other stuff. For example, you might be crossing a river dodging boulders, and then you'll make it across the river and into the prairie where you'll gun down some buffalo. The general order of events never changes (forest-->river-->plains-->desert/second river-->mountain-->freefall-->rapids/present day) but there are special random events that can occur, including everything from unicorns to time travel to pirates, many of which will unlock new wagons.

SAWA is really fun, but also difficult. I've only completed it once, and I had to use the invisible wagon, which has a super tiny hitbox. Thankfully it has a good sense of humor and charming visuals and music to ease the pain of my many, many deaths.

I have come to this point after wasting so much of my life, throwing myself over 20 hours closer to my death, playing this repetitive, poorly balanced, poorly made-in-general piece of ♥♥♥♥ing garbage. OK to start: what it looks like: an absurdist, tongue-in-cheek parody of Oregon Trail (obviously), like the video game equivalent of a Mel Brooks or an old Zucker/Abrahams movie. Is it hard? Artificially, yes. (Undodgeable objects, inability to heal outside of random chance, random drops in health via disease.)
Is it roguelike? Partially. There are random events but only a select few that always occur at the same positions. Example is at the beginning you either get ambushed by Unicorns and fight a dragon or you get ambushed by bandits and fight a machine gun cart.
Is this game entertaining? For a while, then it gets infuriatingly repetitive and boring as you never quite reach the end due to dumb luck. It would also be nice if the other carts weren't god awful or impossible to unlock. Reward players, don't cripple them when the odds are already stacked against them.

EDIT: One really great thing about this game is the soundtrack. Even if the game is repetitive the soundtrack is enjoyable every time. The Great Plains music reminds me of the early days of Ninja Sex Party. Also the soundtrack is in the games files with remixes not in the game, so drop it into your music player of choice if you want to listen on the go.

Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is quite possibly THE most underappreciated game of 2013. The amazing, original soundtrack tickles your eadrums while hilarious visuals keep you entertained throughout the entire game. I've never laughed so hard at an 8-bit game since...Well, ever! Almost every single aspect of Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is either pitch-perfect or incredibly innovative. Props to sparsevector for making a hilarious experience that shouldn't be missed. Super Amazing Wagon Adventure's only flaw is it's incredible difficulty. Although this may be frustrating at times, it's very easy to overlook, considering how much this game does right. Super Amazing Wagon Adventure is an example of what 8-bit titles nowadays should be, and that is why I'm giving Super Amazing Wagon Adventure a 9 out of 10, just shy of a masterpiece. What just makes this game even better is the fact that it's only 3$. So, go buy this game or die at the hands of a little rabid squirrel.
